metadata.case_name: Sheel Chandra (Hindu Undivided Family) v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appellant is a Hindu undivided family with Sheel Chandra as its Karta, consisting of Sheel Chandra and his younger brother.
Sheel Chandra's father, Adishwar Lal, was Treasurer of several branches of the Central Bank of India until his death on April 16, 1950.
During father's lifetime, Sheel Chandra was employed as Overseer in the Bank on salary of Rs. 400 per month.

Sheel Chandra appointed Treasurer of Delhi and sixteen other branches effective April 16, 1950, via agreement dated September 19, 1950; could be appointed to other branches in Punjab, UP, Rajasthan by mutual agreement.
As Treasurer, furnished security from HUF properties: title deeds of immovable properties in Chandni Chowk, Delhi, and Government of India securities worth Rs. 75,000.
HUF owns considerable property: income from house property Rs. 50,000 per annum, stocks, shares, Government securities.
Received Rs. 23,286 from Bank in assessment year 1951-52 as emoluments.
Income-tax Authorities held sum as income of HUF; Appellate Tribunal upheld, construing agreement as profits and gains of business, security from joint family properties.
Tribunal referred two questions under s.66(1) Indian Income-tax Act to Punjab High Court at instance of appellant.
High Court answered both questions against appellant on May 12, 1955: emoluments not salary but profits of business; income of HUF due to family security and father's prior role.

Agreement details: Treasurer to engage subordinate Cash Department Staff (Head Cashiers, Potdars, etc.), control/dismiss with Bank approval; responsible for receipts/payments, genuineness of documents, losses from forgeries, pledged goods staff, enquiries on customers, hundi info, bullion valuation, safe custody, etc.
Remuneration: Rs. 1,750 per month for all branches; additional for guaranteeing certain staff; adjustments for branch changes; staff paid by Bank per its scale.
Agreement terminable by 3 months' notice or forthwith for breach; arbitration clause; Treasurer responsible for staff acts/omissions.

legal_issues.text: Whether, on true construction of agreement between Central Bank of India and Sheel Chandra, salary and emoluments as Treasurer assessable under head 'salary' or 'profits and gains of business'.
Whether Sheel Chandra's emoluments as Treasurer rightly assessed in hands of Hindu undivided family of which he is Karta.

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of agreement show Sheel Chandra was servant of Bank, not independent contractor: monthly salary, termination forthwith in certain cases, duties as directed, liability for losses.

respondent_arguments.text: Agreement shows Sheel Chandra carrying on business: supplying Cash Department Staff for consideration, guaranteeing fidelity (insurance), payments for supplying staff categories, terminable by notice, arbitration, not required to serve personally.
Emoluments income of HUF as acquired with risk/detriment to family property (security furnished); appointed due to father's role and family security.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Gokul Chand v. Firm Hukum Chand; CIT v. Kalu Babu Lal Chand

court_reasoning.text: Agreement creates master-servant relationship, not employer-independent contractor: duties peculiar to Treasurers, Bank control/supervision over Treasurer and staff, integral to Bank's business; guarantees part of duty nature.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test of control/supervision (Dharangadhara Chemical Works); overall effect of agreement.

court_reasoning.text: Emoluments salary of Sheel Chandra individually, not HUF: personal qualifications/experience, no family funds expended for training, mere security furnishing not 'detriment/risk' as in precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No outlay/expenditure/detriment to family property; distinguished Gokul Chand, Kalu Babu.

holdings.text: Emoluments are salary assessable under s.7 Income-tax Act, not s.10 as profits/gains of business.
Salary is individual income of Sheel Chandra, not of HUF.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivanandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar agreement clauses held contract of service, not agency.
Distinction: contract of service integrates into business; contract for services accessory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Short v. J. & W. Henderson Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Indicia of contract of service: selection, remuneration, control method of work, suspension/dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Test: due control/supervision by employer given nature of work.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.P. Bhargava v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Different contract terms; guarantee commission agency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lala Jeewan Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Commission agency under Excess Profits Tax Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kalu Babu Lal Chand
precedents_cited.relevance: Karta's MD remuneration from family-financed company business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokul Chand v. Firm Hukum Chand Nath Mal
precedents_cited.relevance: Family funds expended for qualifications; 'risk/detriment' in that context.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court; salary head vs. profits/gains of business.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and order set aside. Emoluments held salary under s.7, individual income of Sheel Chandra, not HUF income under s.10.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court judgment set aside in favour of appellant.

key_quotes.text: "the Treasurer in the instant case must be held to be a servant of the Bank."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "mere ability to furnish a substantial security is not the sole or even the main reason for being appointed to such a responsible post."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects HUF income claim based on security.

key_quotes.text: "It is difficult to lay down any one test to distinguish the relationship of master and servant from that of an employer and independent contractor."
key_quotes.speaker: court
